statement:
[**Theorem**]{} [@singer; @kelley] Suppose $f\colon X\to Y$ is a
continuous map between topological spaces $X$ and $Y$. If $X$ is compact
and $f$ is surjective, then $Y$ is compact.

The inclusion map $[0,1]\hookrightarrow[0,2)$ shows that the requirement
for $f$ to be surjective cannot be omitted. If $X$ is compact and $f$ is
continuous we can always conclude, however, that $f(X)$ is compact,
since .

*Proof of theorem.* (Following [@singer].) Suppose
$\{V_\alpha \mid \alpha \in I\}$ is an arbitrary open cover for $f(X)$.
Since $f$ is continuous, it follows that
$$\{f^{-1} (V_\alpha) \mid \alpha \in I\}$$ is a collection of open sets
in $X$. Since $A\subseteq f^{-1} f (A)$ for any $A\subseteq X$, and
since the inverse commutes with unions (see ), we have $$\begin{aligned}
X &\subseteq & f^{-1} f(X) \\
  &= & f^{-1} \big( \bigcup_{\alpha \in I} (V_\alpha)\big) \\
  &=& \bigcup_{\alpha \in I} f^{-1}(V_\alpha).\end{aligned}$$ Thus
$\{ f^{-1}(V_\alpha) \mid \alpha \in I\}$ is an open cover for $X$.
Since $X$ is compact, there exists a finite subset $J\subseteq I$ such
that $\{ f^{-1}(V_\alpha) \mid \alpha \in J\}$ is a finite open cover
for $X$. Since $f$ is a surjection, we have $ff^{-1}(A)=A$ for any
$A\subseteq Y$ (see ). Thus $$\begin{aligned}
f(X) &= & f \big(\bigcup_{i\in J} f^{-1}(V_\alpha)\big)\\
     &= & ff^{-1} \bigcup_{i\in J} f^{-1}(V_\alpha)\\
     &=&  \bigcup_{i\in J} V_\alpha.\end{aligned}$$ Thus
$\{ V_\alpha \mid \alpha \in J\}$ is an open cover for $f(X)$, and
$f(X)$ is compact. $\Box$

A shorter proof can be given using the :

*Shorter proof.* Suppose $\{A_i\mid i\in I\}$ is a collection of closed
subsets of $Y$ with the finite intersection property. Then
$\{f^{-1}(A_i)\mid i\in I\}$ is a collection of closed subsets of $X$
with the finite intersection property, because if $F\subseteq I$ is
finite then
$$\bigcap_{i\in F} f^{-1}(A_i) = f^{-1}\!\left(\,\bigcap_{i\in F} A_i\!\right),$$
which is nonempty as $f$ is a surjection. As $X$ is compact, we have
$$f^{-1}\left(\,\bigcap_{i\in I} A_i\!\right) = \bigcap_{i\in I} f^{-1}(A_i) \neq \emptyset$$
and so $\bigcap_{i\in I} A_i\neq \emptyset$. Therefore $Y$ is compact.
$\Box$

[9]{} I.M. Singer, J.A.Thorpe, *Lecture Notes on Elementary Topology and
Geometry*, Springer-Verlag, 1967. J.L. Kelley, *General Topology*, D.
van Nostrand Company, Inc., 1955. G.J. Jameson, *Topology and Normed
Spaces*, Chapman and Hall, 1974.
